Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: You will gain a high-level understanding of a bunch of AI-related topics. And you'll get to try implementing these topics in weekly assignments.

Great survey course of the history and current methods of AI, writ large. Covers everything from knowledge representation (you thought you were done with logic once you finished 202??) to computer vision.

AI from historical to modern-day techniques, including: search, heuristic search, game-playing, constraint satisfaction problems, planning, supervised learning, neural networks, deep learning, natural language, vision, applications of AI to the modern world.
I got a broad overview of what AI has encompassed in the past, and what it encompasses now.
The fundamentals of AI including reinforcement learning, neural networks, first order logical, AI and ethics, etc.
A wide variety artificial intelligence techniques in theory and in practice through psets; definitely good brush-up on Python programming and interpreting someone else's complex code base
Learned about the basis and subfields of AI.
Fundamentals of artificial intelligence

I learned so much! I actually feel like I know how many amazing AI sytems work! We programmed a othello playing and AI, an ant produced through genetic algorithms, a reinforcement learning pacman and so much more!
Learned a lot about different AI techniques

- A basic overview of the general and technical strategies in use by modern AI systems. These include search, inference, planning, machine learning, and more.
- Reinforcement of my knowledge about data structures and how to use them to solve real-world problems.
- An appreciation for the power of the Python programming language (and some skills in writing code in it).
- A more nuanced view of modern AI technologies and their impact on the world, from autonomous vehicles, to healthcare, to marketing.
AI techniques, some AI history and current events/technologies
I did not learn that much in this class. It is a survey course, so does not give you further information than the basics that you could get by looking up the word "artificial intelligence" in Google.
Survey course on various AI topics and fields
I learned a lot about AI from a high level. Great class.
I got a survey level knowledge of most things that pertain to AI.
Current topics in AI, basic and adversarial search, introduction to many interesting topics like neural networks.
We dove pretty in-depth into search spaces and motion planning, and then we also explored (in a little less depth) vision, NLP, supervised learning, and reinforcement learning.
I learned a lot about every part of the AI field, including Neural Nets, decision trees, deep learning, robotics, autonomous cars, as well as practical experience in a bunch of those areas.
This course taught me search, different types of intelligent agents, and different methods of deep learning and neural networks in Python
A general survey of AI, with topics like: intelligent search, logic, planning, learning (my favorite), robotics, and ethics. Programming in Python.
I got a really good sense of the field of AI and where it started and where its at now. We got a good overview of all the classic AI techniques and the direction where AI is going.

I learned the pioneering techniques of modern artificial intelligence, starting with basic search, informed search, heuristics, constraint satisfaction, supervised learning, neural networks, perceptrons, deep neural networks, convolutional neural networks, reinforcement learning techniques such as q-learning, and unsupervised learning such k-means. I applied these to practical fields such as autonomous vehicles, healthcare and discussions on ethics.
Search techniques, how to use logic and basic introduction to NLP, Reinforcement and Machine Learning.
I learned about the history of artificial intelligence and many of the underlying algorithms and techniques that are used today.
Broad overview of the field of AI, including search problems, logics, constraint satisfaction problems, neural networks, supervised and unsupervised learning, and reinforcement learning.
Ml
Survey of artificial intelligence topics, programming in Python
This is a pretty high level review of basic AI topics. The class is cool if you don't know much about AI and want to learn
Learned about different areas in artificial intelligence.

I learned a wide variety of artificial intelligence techniques and history of the field, including supervised and reinforced learning. We learned about genetic algorithms, configuration spaces, the ethics of AI and much more.
Various topics in Artificial Intelligence
An absolutely essential introduction to AI. No CS student in this century should get through undergrad without taking this class!
I learned a lot about how AI systems work and how they improve themselves based on statistical methods

CPSC 470 provided a wide overview of many topics related to artificial intelligence. We started with basic search algorithms and how to make them better. We then moved on to planning and first-order logic. Afterwards, I learned about communication and visual perception. We ended the class with my favorite parts on AI and different sectors such as medicine, ethics, and the future!

AI was a survey course about many different topics, as well as the history, of AI. At the beginning and middle of the course we follow the textbook and go through some general concepts that are important in AI, and by the last few lectures the lectures were on more specific topics that had gained traction in recent years. I developed my skills in coding in Python.
I was able to learn much more about the overall field of Artificial Intelligence, gaining a greater grasp of its history and current state.
One of my FAVORITE classes of Yale, ever. Learn all the good hot topics from informed searching to game playing against AI bots to image recognition!!
I gained a very broad knowledge over most developments going on in the field of artificial intelligence and some key algorithms that are widely used today.

Learned about searching and game-playing techniques, the logical foundations of AI, techniques like neural nets and reinforcement learning (and how to apply them to handwriting recognition and image processing, etc.), domains such as NLP and robotics, and the societal and ethical implications of AI in general.
I learned a broad array of AI concepts: Decision Tree, Genetic Algorithm, Neural Network, Reinforcement Learning, Computer Vision, etc...
I gained a lot of knowledge about different concepts in AI, including different agents, searching techniques, and neural networks.
A great survey class for AI

You will learn a broad array of AI techniques, including various approaches to problems, whether that be a basic search or a more developed neural network. Many people view AI has a black box into which you toss a problem that will output a solution, but it really is much more nuanced than that - in this class you will discuss how to know when one should apply a given technique as well as their relative strengths and weaknesses.
Broad exposure to many fields of AI, such as machine learning, computer vision, robotics, and underlying methods such as search and planning
Survey course about the basics of AI and the technologies historically and currently used in this field.
Broad knowledge of concepts in artificial intelligence
I learned how to develop logic for basic games.
I learned more about the different topics in AI.
good introduction to relevant topics in AI and machine learning, so that when someone says AI you actually know what they are talking about, probably more
Introductory concepts in Artificial Intelligence.

I got a solid overview of artificial intelligence. I had taken previous courses in computer vision and natural language processing but still got a lot out of the class. It filled in a lot of gaps for me !
I learned about a variety of topics relating to Artificial Intelligence, machine learning techniques, and AI's affect on the real world.
a survey of importance topics in artificial intelligence, and a review of ones I've learned previously
survey of AI topics and challenges

This class was an excellent survey course of all things Artificial Intelligence. I made the mistake of taking it after having already taken Computer Vision and Natural Language Processing, so I felt that I did not learn as much as I would have if I had taken it as, say, a first-year or sophomore. Thus, I think it is a great class, but definitely an introductory level one. Assignments are not too difficult and are fairly interesting, and Scaz is a great lecturer.
I gained a wide overview of AI including it's history to contemporary techniques. I really appreciated the survey style course.

This course offered a pretty wide and well-thought-out survey of techniques in AI past and present, building from the ground-up: search, game-playing, logic and knowledge representation, planning, supervised learning, reinforcement learning, some unsupervised learning. Yes, including deep neural nets, as well as some applications like NLP and perception and robotics. I also really enjoyed the last few classes, focusing on current and future issues in AI/society. For skills, I developed an entry-level comfort with most/all of those techniquesbut note, this is definitely meant to be a survey/sampling of a lot of different material, and I wouldn't say I developed immense experience with any single topic. This was my first course in Python (coming form cs50+201+223) and I definitely feel comfortable using it for just about anything nowthe intensity and pacing of psets worked pretty well to facilitate learning there.
Foundational survey knowledge about the algorithms and methods used across artificial intelligence fields and their applications.
Very good overview of AI topics and actual coding skills for AI!
I learned the basics of artificial intelligence and the algorithms associated with it.
Broad survey course, so a little information about a lot of things
A broad overview of the different technologies in AI, the challenges, the wins, and what is currently happening in the AI world.
I learned the basics about AI.
weaknesses -- too few office hours

This course rips its psets from Berkeley, and it's sometimes too obvious. Although the psets are interesting, there's more than should be done to make them Yale-specific to reduce the risk of students copying Berkeley answers from github or using them as references to figure out their own solutions. Also the wording can be awkward.

Scaz is a great lecturer too so he helps make the class great. 

Meeting on Fridays is an L too.

Strengths: Scaz is an amazing lecturer, material is presented in an engaging and accessible way.
Weaknesses: the problem sets tested your ability to write a few lines of code in an otherwise complete (and complicated, and sometimes incomprehensible) codebase, rather than actual knowledge of AI concepts. CS474 does a way better job of teaching many of these concepts through problem sets.

This is a huge survey class. That means that the material can't be too hard or in depth. That can be frustrating if you actually want to take much away from the class -- I felt that the psets did not facilitate learning very much -- they were either too simplified to actually make us learn the material, or they were complicated in a way that had almost nothing to do with the material.

Strengths: great introduction to different topics, Scaz is a great lecturer
Weaknesses: psets were sometimes difficult to understand and spelled out for us

Strengths: great, enthusiastic prof; pretty interesting, applicable course material to anyone caught up in the usual theoretical CS
Weaknesses: Breadth over depth (fair decision) in terms of material covered; we never really got to develop our own AI from scratch and modified others' very minimally

Scaz is a great lecturer, and his research is at an interesting subsection.  The 2nd half of the semester the course structure felt super rushed though (PSETs due every week instead of every 1.5-2 weeks), so I'd recommend placing another PSET before the midterm to evenly distribute the workload.
A bit more guidance in lecture

The guest lectures throughout the semester were very interesting. 

While this course is intended to be a broad survey of many different topics in AI, I do wish the course could have gone into more detail in a few of the topics.

There were one or two assignments (such as #4 planning in blocks world) where I found the assignment instructions rather difficult to understand due to typos, and inconsistent names between the instructions and source code.

I thought this class was great! I thought the psets and grading were very reasonable and lecture was always really good and interesting. 
The room for improvement would be more office hours and more clarity in the answers that TAs specifically made on piazza
Additionally, I feel like the final was a bit of a curveball. We were told that it would be similar to the midterm but it had a very different style of questions. I was also surprised by some of the questions because they didn't seem like things we covered deeply in class. I ended up studying what I thought was most emphasized but that was bad. I think a practice exam would be extremely helpful.
Scaz is a great lecturer. Spent a ton of time on search though, perhaps doesn't need as much focus going forward.

Strengths:
- Broad coverage. I learned a _lot_ about different techniques used in AI and feel prepared and excited to jump into more advanced treatments of specific applications.
- Well-taught. While there was a mountain of material to cover, Scaz did a great job of distilling the most important points and emphasizing those, making exams and problem sets very fair relative to the topics discussed in class. I was free to explore the nitty-gritty details on my own if I wanted, but spending 10 hours a week reading a textbook was not required for success in the course.
- Shorter, more frequent class meetings. I really enjoyed the MWF 50 minute lecture structure, compared to the typical MW/TTh 75 minute lecture structure of most CS classes at Yale. For one, it allowed for a more natural cover of a wide range of topics. For another, it kept me focused and attentive and consistently thinking about the material.

Weaknesses:
- There are too many students in this course relative to the teaching staff. One simple way to improve on this is is to make 223 a prerequisite, as this course requires solid knowledge of data structures and basic programming.
- The content was, at times, a bit too high-level. While I recognize that a survey course doesn't allow for much time to explore any of the topics in detail, I felt coddled on some of the problem sets relative to my experiences in other CS classes at Yale.
- There was no small-scale environment to discuss weighty course material, especially for the topics covered in the last couple of weeks. I would have greatly appreciated a discussion section component of the course, if only for those two weeks, to be able to talk about these topics with my peers in a more intimate environment. Alternatively, the class could be made much smaller, but it would be mildly unfair to students to cap enrollment in such a desired subject area.

I think it's a really fun course with interesting psets and lectures, but sometimes I did wish the homework assignments were proofread a little bit more. There were often typos/vague language that were only clarified if you happened to check piazza or ask in person.

It covers relevant topics. However, it is far too broad and provides no knowledge on the insights as to how any of the AI technology works. I have learned about many technologies and came out with absolutely no idea how to implement them. I would not mind the course being harder, if the psets were more than writing just 5 lines of code into an already complete assignment.

Scaz is a great lecturer. He made lectures enjoyable and engaging, and super organized. He also made great problem sets which built off of what we learned in lecture AND challenged us to really learn something from them.  Problem sets were manageable and fair. The course could have benefited from more office hours and ULAs/TAs.
Good survey on general knowledge, but homework could be more comprehensive to help understand the inner workings of the techniques discussed in class.
Great survey course. I wish more of the assignments were from the ground up and more difficult. There should be an advanced AI class.

Strengths: Scaz is a great lecturer, very clear when teaching material and not hard to reach via Piazza or email. Some TAs were also good resources.

Weaknesses: Office hours for AI were high in demand yet not offered for a long time. Each TA only worked one hour-long shift and each day was a max of 3 shifts.
Scaz is so great. Amazing lecturer, the structure of the course was very good and facilitated in-depth learning of many topics.
Scaz is a very engaging lecturer, but there is a lot of material trying to be covered.  I feel like I didn't learn a whole lot from most of the assignments, and the exams were lowkey brutal.

This is a survey in one of the broadest fields extant in computer science; it is understandably difficult to cover everything in a satisfactory manner. I think it would be much improved with a focus on the latter half of the semester (as taught this year) with more in-depth assignments.

I wish there were more levels of this class. I came from a heavy linear algebra background, and found myself wishing that I could have done deeper psets that involved actual math. Scaz explained the need to keep the prerequisites for the course minimal was the cause of this, and I understand that, but still wish Yale had more varied & deeper CS electives.

This class was taught survey style, so it gave me a lot of insights into different areas of AI. On the other hand, because it was a survey course, we were not able to learn about anything in an in depth manner. I liked the survey style overall because it showed me bits and pieces, and now I know which specific classes I want to take in the future.
Scaz made this class the best Ive taken as part of the CS major. Good assignments, great lectures, and the material was really interesting.

I thought the course did a good job of giving exactly what it said it was going to: a survey of the field of AI. It doesn't go too in-depth into any one area which may be frustrating to some, but it gives a holistic picture of AI as a field of study.

Strengths: one of the best courses in the CS department, problem sets are so fun because you are applying and building real AI systems (with a bit of help of course), and Scaz is one of the best, most passionate and well-spoken professors in the department. He has deep knowledge of AI, and I definitely recommend this class. Weaknesses: it may not be offered again because there is a lack of staffing in CS department, which would be an absolute bummer.
could be less broad and more in depth

Strengths: The lecturer (Scaz) was very clear and engaging. 
Weaknesses: The homework assignments were duplicated from other CS courses. This means students from those courses learned less, and students who are not yet initiated have to spend much more time. The final exam was very difficult and it tested many obscure concepts.

The course is a good overview course but I think it could benefit from making CS223 an official prereq and going somewhat deeper into certain topics. There are a lot of psets for a CS course but most of them take under 3 hours to complete which means that you don't learn much. I did enjoy the guest lecturers and being able to use a cheat sheet for the tests was super helpful since there were a lot of facts covered. Also making this class twice a week instead of three times a week would improve it.

The topics that are covered are very broad, and I liked how the lectures had slides that were very well-made. It was clear that Scaz is an expert in this field, and that he was trying to give us as good of an overview as possible. That being said, the problem sets were more simple than I would've liked, and I felt like I was just following instructions on the psets rather than actually learning and solving problems. It seems as though a course that was labelled as CS470 would have delved deeper into the material. I would've liked a pset that allowed us to learn more about neural networks, or something that allowed us to implement qlearning for a real problem rather than just plugging in the equation.
Learned a lot

Strengths: Scaz is a fantastic lecturer. He is incredibly engaging and funny, and he clearly wants his class to succeed. The exams themselves are incredibly fair (I'd say on the easier side), so don't be too stressed.

Weaknesses: The course is way too broad. We cover a topic a week, and problem sets touch on only a few subtopics of each topic. I'm not saying that breadth is a bad thing, but I feel like I wouldn't be able to implement most of AI techniques we learned this semester. In addition, the reading is completely useless. The textbook goes in significantly more depth than Scaz' lectures (so much so that I've taken another class based on just 1 or 2 chapters in the book). Scaz will also say the exam can test anything from lecture and the reading, but I personally did not do any of the readings and still knew everything on both exams.
Scaz is a good lecturer and he makes the lectures interesting
I wish we spent more time on certain topics.

Its a survey course, though I liked it a lot. The problem sets made us practice and implement the most important concepts from lecture, and in lecture we were exposed to a ton of content. Some of the later psets were easy which is nice, but maybe a bit too easy and would have been nice to have to practice harder material a bit more.
Covers a lot, and not very in depth, but the problem sets aren't super great for learning the things that are covered on the exams.

Scaz gave fascinating and clear lectures that kept things interesting and gave great introduction to the major topics in AI. However, in addition to the pset schedule getting very rushed, the psets felt poorly constructed from past assignments or different courses, and there wasnt enough help available via office hours or piazza.
This was a very organized course given how many students enrolled. At times, it felt like it could have been more challenging (in terms of programming) but I thoroughly enjoyed it!

More office hours and more practice materials for both of the exams would have been helpful. The lectures had a very logical path and were easy to understand, although sometimes the class ran over by a few minutes.

I really enjoyed this course, I felt that there was a disparity between the level of material we were responsible for in the whole course and the final exam. However, on the whole I thought it was a great course.
The course is great, wonderful piazza presence and TAs

I loved Professor Scazs style of teaching! Despite the large size of the class, the lectures were never boring because Scaz described the class material with big enthusiasm and engagement. However, the class would have been even nicer if the staff for the class had been bigger.

Strengths: I thought Scaz was an excellent professor: very engaging lectures and he did a great job in balancing the course content between concepts and techniques and applications. The ULAs were also super helpful. The psets were well-designed to introduce us to applications of what we learned in class, often in very interesting domains. Weaknesses: the psets did vary greatly in difficulty, starting out quite difficult and then becoming easier, to the point of being almost *too* easy; at the end I didn't feel as if I were actually learning the technique but rather just copying code from the spec. The specs themselves were often confusingly worded and ambiguous. Overall though, one of my favorite classes at Yale!
Scaz is a very good lecturer. The course has good structure. However, reading thousands of lines of other people's code for almost every Python programming assignment was quite a pain.
The office hours need more support, but the lectures are very good and I enjoyed the psets.

I think the strengths are that it is a really engaging class (w/ Scaz as prof.) - lectures were always very interesting and fun to attend. I personally would've wanted to spend a little more time on the math side of some of the algorithms (really getting an understanding of how exactly everything is happening), but I get that it would be less accessible if it did (so it's definitely a trade-off).

This class was extremely well organized and administered, especially given the large size of the class. The lectures were fascinating and well put together, and Scaz did a great job of showing both the effectiveness and problems of each topic. I would have liked there to be more office hours or more individual feedback!

It definitely covered very interesting content! Problem sets were also fun and interesting and make you really think about the technologies you were leaning about. Professor taught incredibly well. Course support was also well structures with the office hours, TAs and the Piazza. The guest lectures were also cool. Overall great course, wouldn't really change anything.
The course contains really interesting topics and a lot of the ones covered give a great idea of how the technology actually works. However, the assignments lacked depth (even for a survey course).
The topics covered are very exciting, as AI is a rapidly growing field, although there are quite a few, so most of what you learn will not be too in depth.
It covers very broad sections of AI which is very informational. Could be improved by going more in depth into some areas

I liked that the class covered a wide variety of topics, allowing you to understand different areas in AI; however, I think the course would have been better if it had covered fewer topics but gone into more depth for each topic. The lectures were engaging and interesting. The problem sets in the class could have been more rigorous / done a better job of reinforcing the material we learned in class.

Strengths - how many different topics in AI we covered
Weaknesses - knowing how much detail we were expected to know for each of these topics

There are way to many psets for this class and very few of them went in depth. I would much rather have fewer psets that are harder/ require us to code the program from scratch. This class quickly became an exercise in understanding the starter code implementations than actually understanding the concepts at hand, which was extremely disappointing. This course was also understaffed, although this might be a departmental problem more so than a course specific problem. 

A strength of this course was that Scaz is a great lecturer.

Strengths: Very digestible and accessible to all students. Topics were extremely interesting and definitely helped me to learn more about AI.

Weaknesses: By nature of being a survey course, the class did not have time to go into many of the details. So, I do not feel like I know enough to actually implement many of the AI techniques we talked about.

Scaz is a great lecturer. Definitely one of the best of the CS department. I thought that the psets were not the best. Some of them were a bit too easy and made it hard to internalize the material. Others had guidelines that weren't too clear and had grading guidelines that were not too clear.

The strength of the course is definitely Scaz - he is one of the few great CS lecturers in the department and you feel extremely engaged in class. The weakness is that at least this semester, there was too much overlap with the Intelligent Robotics class, and it felt like there was a lot more in the field of AI that we could have covered.

I wish we could have gone a lot deeper into some of the topics, especially the machine learning units. A lot of the psets felt very surface level, but did a good job at helping me understand the big picture underlying concepts.

Lectures and slides are great and programming assignments are interesting. However, I felt like we were spoon-fed most of the time because the psets were very hand-holding and could be completed without much understanding. The midterm also relied a lot more on knowledge than on understanding. I would love the course if it went more into the theory and math behind concepts e.g. backpropagation.
topics were broad and provided a nice introduction to the field. the problem sets supplemented the topics nicely
a good survey course for learning about topics in AI, needs more TAs and office hours this year since help was pretty limited and there were often bugs in the starter code

I think this course would have been improved if it was not at 10:30 am or three days a week. I thoroughly enjoyed every lecture that I attended, however if the lectures had been at 11:35 or in the afternoon I probably would have attended more of them.

I felt that the coding was often too straightforward for some of the assignments, and that the steps of the algorithms that we had to implement were too obvious and did not leave much for us to reason through and figure out. That being said, I thought the problem sets were all extremely interesting.

I think that the broadness of the course is definitely a strength. This may only be desirable on hindsight but I felt like there could have been fewer problem sets but more comprehensive, such that we have more experience in putting together things like neural nets. I felt a good example of a pset was the generic algorithm, because we basically had to write that from scratch. (Kind of)

Big strength: Scaz is a great professor. His lectures are clear, and he also clearly cares about his students. I'm also glad the course got to cover such a breadth of material. Weaknesses? I do wish the material had been more heavily weighted towards more recent techniques, developments, and societal issues; in general, it felt like each topic was given roughly equal time. I think this is less of a weakness with the class, though, and more of a weakness with the department: the CS dept, and Yale at-large, is sorely lacking in its range of AI/ML offerings and professors; I wish this course didn't have to try to cram everything relevant to AI (from technical skills to history to practical applications, etc) into one single semester. One other, smaller weakness: oftentimes, the psets covering more complicated concepts would come with an existing codebase, and problems were more "fill-in-the-blank 'YOUR CODE HERE'" style. Although it was really nice /not/ having to create such large codebases from scratch, oftentimes I found the structural/algorithmic setups to be unintuitive, inefficient, or otherwise difficult-to-make-sense-of given the way we had learned concepts in lecture. I wish more efforts were made to (1) align pset methods with those taught in lecture, (2) better document why the codebases are designed as they are.

Strengths: 
- Professor was an amazing lecturer.
- The problem sets are reasonable and reinforce the material well without excess tedium. 

Weaknesses:
- Not enough ULA/support staff.
Lectures were amazing, really. Problem sets were not hard but still you could actually learn with them.

This course does not properly teach us how we can write our own artificial intelligence algorithms. The biggest thing that you learn is how to read python code and fill in left out pieces. It would have been better if we could have coded ai algorithms from scratch. They also fail to grade to a standard that reflects students' hard work because the pset grades don't reflect that; instead they reflect the knowledge that some students already have of where to look for the proper pseudocode in the book or the advice of other students who know something that they learned at office hours and nowhere else.

Scaz is a good lecturer and the material is interesting. Exams were difficult and kind of hard to prepare for. Material is really broad and if you took Intelligent Robotics or NLP it was a lot of repeated material.

The material was interesting and we got a good overview of the different areas in AI. But at the same time, we brushed over some off the topics super quickly and for some of the psets that didn't involve coding it seemed like we were doing very surface-level work. I understand that it's not possible to go in depth into every topic in a survey course, but I felt very very unsatisfied with the way we learnt some of the topics. Scaz is a great instructor and did his best to show us the most interesting things. The TAs were also amazing, putting in several extra hours to help us, but like with most CS classes, getting help in office hours was close to impossible. The final was pretty bad and just had so so much material. Overall though, I felt like the class was super interesting and I learnt a bunch of really cool stuff!

The weaknesses of this course are that I feel like the problem sets did not facilitate my learning or understanding of the course material. The psets were not hard and didn't take much time, but the exams were confusing and often felt like they tested information that was a needle in the haystack of the 30+ lecture slides. Lectures were good and engaging; however, they were very broad and covered so much material that it was extremely hard to gauge what we would be tested on and in what format.
Yes, AI is a fundamental topic in computer science that everyone should know before graduating.
Definitely

I would recommend this class to anyone who is interested in AI or the history of AI. This class is very much a survey class of all things related to AI, which is both good and bad. You really get a comprehensive overview of AI from basic search to neural nets, but you never go really in-depth into any one concept. The psets in this class were very fair, some were challenging, some less so. The psets were pretty good overall but it seemed like they could have been designed better. Feedback was good on some psets but not others. Fairly solid CS elective.

If you want a gutty ish CS class and don't mind survey courses, yes, take this with Scaz. Scaz is a wonderful lecturer and you will enjoy and glean something from the lectures. The psets aren't bad although you may not learn too much from them.

I would definitely recommend this class, especially with Scaz. The lectures were all very engaging, and the guest lecturers were also great. Psets are relatively straightforward and the midterm exam was extremely fair (one page of notes given, as well as two for the final).
CS majors looking for an interesting applicable elective; taking it as a first-year is doable with decent preparation in Python and any level of experience in the topics covered

Yes - especially with Scaz.  Such interesting content which is essential for modern day tech jobs.  Know though that Scaz teaches the course at a high-level but expects you to learn all low-level content: while we gloss over algorithms in class, you still need to implement them thoroughly on PSETs, and you still need to know details of techniques (i.e. convolution) for exams.
Yes, it is a good introduction to AI
Yes definitely! Scaz makes topics in AI very accessible via emphasis on concepts and methods without requiring extreme amounts of time spent programming/debugging.
Yes! Take is with Scaz! He is great and the class is really fun. This is the most interesting and best taught CS class I have taken at Yale.
If Scaz is teaching, yes! If not, idk! This is a fun intro to AI but don't expect to get much depth at all.

If Scaz is teaching it, definitely. But it might not be exactly what you expect. Be warned ye who enter here, this course covers a _lot_ of material. It is intended as a survey, so you won't get especially deep into any one topic (if you're looking for a class on neural networks, then take a class on neural networks, not an intro to AI course), but you will walk away with a broad overview of many different kinds of techniques used in modern AI systems (from search to language processing to motion planning). Scaz does a great job of helping you to navigate the mess of topics though, keeping your eyes focused on the big picture rather than the minutiae. Note that this course mostly skims over the most difficult technical aspects of AI, so if you're looking for something that will really challenge your linear algebra or Python knowledge, this course is not for you. Regardless, I found it a great way to explore a vast portion of the AI "toolbox" and try my hand at implementing some simple code to put it into action. It was fun, informative, and well-taught, and I would highly recommend it to anyone interested in a survey course on a topic that is becoming increasingly relevant to the modern world.
Yes, it was interesting material and the psets span a wide range of skills/knowledge and are relatively fun
Yes, anyone who's interested in the topic and/or majoring in computer science.

I would not recommend this. There is almost nothing to be gained from taking this class, unless you are a first-time CS student. It should not be a CS elective. This is more like AI for non-CS majors.
I would definitely recommend this course if Scaz is teaching it. This course is multidisciplinary and many students could enjoy it and pick up real skills in AI from it.
Yes; scaz is an amazing lecturer, and you will get an idea of what AI technologies are relevant today and what their applications are.
Great survey course of AI. Good to know what practical skills cs can have.
I would recommend this class to people interested in AI when Scaz hopefully teaches this class again.
It's a great class and a good exposure to past and current topics in AI

If you're a young CS student like me looking to branch out into the world of AI, this a good place to start, and you will likely be highly engaged with the lectures.  But it's not an easy class and it's hard to engage with assignments where you're only writing about 10-20 lines of code in a gigantic python notebook and then answering short answer questions about the rest of the code that someone wrote for you.  Don't look here for a gut if Scaz is teaching it.
Yes! This is a fascinating course and if you take it with Scaz, he's a gem of a lecturer. His lectures held my attention every time even though the class was m/w/f at 10:30.
I would definitely recommend this class to anyone interested in AI because it gives them a good idea of what the field looks like.
Yes, if you know how to program, this class is a must take. AI is so interesting!

Yes! If you're interested in AI, it's a good course to give you a flavor for the field and see if you want to pursue it further. It's not too difficult and the course is extremely well structured when Scaz is teaching it. Each lecture is focused and the assignments do a great job of teaching you how to apply different AI techniques. It is a survey course, though, so it doesn't go super in-detail in any one topic.
Yes, it's the most applied and hands-on CS class! I recommend it to people of all majors.
no
Take it with Scaz for some light, engaging lectures. Maybe don't take it if you've already taken similar classes.
Yes, if they're curious about AI. However, I think students who have already completed CS223 get more out of the course.
Yes, but
Yes good class
If you're looking for a chill CS elective, then I recommend this course. Out of all the professors that teach AI, Scaz is definitely the best.
Yes, take it with Scaz
Yes if you want an introduction to AI topics.

Yes, this is a great introductory course when taught by Scaz. He is a fantastic lecturer and knows the material better than anyone. He mentioned this class might not be offered next year due to lack of staff, and that is a real shame. Yale's CS department is weaker than other top level universities to begin with, and we need to keep this course. Its a must, its a great intro to AI, the future of CS.
Yes. Does a decent enough job of covering introductory topics in AI

Nice survey course. Could use some more depth and some of the psets didn't feel as constructive as they could've been. I left the class wanting a little more in all the areas, which is a product of a survey course, but also due to there not being many options to pursue these subjects further in the department. Worth taking, but don't expect an amazing class that will change your life.
Especially if Scaz is teaching it, this is a great class. The topics are actually relevant to real-world CS, which is wild for a Yale CS class so you shouldnt miss out.

Absolutely! The p-sets are fun and not super challenging! Scaz is an amazing professor and I really liked that the lectures were 3x a week, for about 50 minutes a class--it allowed us to cover more material but the time went by very quickly!
Yes, if you want to learn about the foundation of artificial intelligence, you should take this class. Scaz is a clear lecturer and good professor.
I would because it is the first and only course about Artifical intelligence offered at Yale, an expanding and important field.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. It is a great way to get a general understanding of various fields that are involved in artificial intelligence, and it gives you a good high-level understanding of all of them. The class also did a good job at making the topics flow in a manner so that it wasn't a complete change of pace going from one topic to the next.
Yes!! Scaz is amazing

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to any students who is interested in artificial intelligence. Especially considering the importance of AI today, this class can be a very valuable experience for even non-CS majors.

Yes, was my favorite CS class taken at Yale so far! I am disappointed that it will most likely not be offered next year, because I found it to both be technically advanced (especially the early psets on writing search and game-playing algorithms) and very well-connected to real-world applications and the implications of AI. It is very well-taught and useful even to non-CS majors, and it's not more difficult than it should be.
Yes. I would recommend any prospective CS major to take this course if it is taught by Scaz.
Yes, it was a great CS elective, I learned a lot!

Yes, but I would caution that it does spend on a fair amount of time on topics which are not immediately thought of as AI (e.g. search), and does not touch deeply on the more conventional topic of neural networks.

Absolutely - I enjoyed the class and I think that it gives a really solid foundation for any future, or more particular, study in the field. The workload is not bad for a CS class and assignments are of manageable length. You'll definitely learn a good amount in the class, and I'd definitely recommend it. I wasn't initially sure if I wanted to take this course, but I'm glad that I did. If Scaz is teaching this class, definitely take it.

Yes, I would recommend this course if you are new to AI and would like to be exposed to many aspects of the field. If you already have extensive experience with AI, I would suggest taking a more specialized, in-depth course in the CS department.
For sure, very interesting content and reasonable workload. Would not recommend to someone seeking to do a more highly technical course- this is basically a survey course in nature.
I would recommend this class if you want a very very broad overview. You don't receive any depth in the material and gain a very rudimentary understanding of various AI topics
Yes I recommend it especially if you want a broad overview of what AI is.

I would recommend this course to someone who is interested in AI and has not already taken Intelligent Robotics (CPSC472). Otherwise, there's enough overlap between the two courses that taking AI might not be as worth it.

I would recommend because AI is such a hot topic, and it's nice to actually have some insight into what AI is when people use the term all the time. Also not super difficult relative to required courses for the CS major, and a more interesting one.

If you need a cs elective take this course. Scaz is a good lecturer. There are a lot of psets, and some of them are a little annoying, but they're usually reasonable. Keep in mind, however, that this is a survey course. Scaz will tell you that on day one. If you are looking to get really in depth in deep learning, vision etc. this is not the course for you. The psets don't really require you to understand these concepts so much as understand starter code implementations.

Yes, to anyone interested in AI. This is a great survey course that covers a lot of different topics. However, for those seeking a more rigorous treatment of AI, I suggest you take some upper-level grad electives instead.
Definitely! I think that Scaz did a great job of covering a ton in an engaging way.

Yes, if Scaz is teaching it you will have a great time! Definitely recommend taking a class with Scaz, but do not recommend taking both Intelligent Robotics and AI with him as there is too much overlap.
I would recommend this course to any CS students that are interested in AI and a moderately challenging and rewarding elective.

It's a good course if you're looking for an overview of AI and/or if you want a programming course suitable for beginners. Otherwise, it doesn't delve very deep into understanding the theory behind AI.

good survey course of high-level concepts. don't expect to be an expert in ML or robotics by the end of this, but you do learn the limitations and progress of AI research which is pretty cool. psets aren't very hard and you usually have 10 days for each one.

I would absolutely recommend this course to freshmen or sophomores who have taken or are concurrently taking 223 since I think it provides an excellent introduction to the next stages of computer science electives. I would not recommend it to someone who has already taken other machine learning courses at Yale.

I would 100% recommend this course. Scaz is a great lecturer and makes difficult topics seem very clear, so it is really important to attend lecture. The topics are all very interesting and across a wide range of fields but are not covered in too much depth. Problem sets are also interesting and not too challenging - the challenge in this class comes from understanding the concepts well rather than from difficult programming assignments. Overall, one of my favorite classes at Yale, and very relevant to the current research in AI.
Yes, and be prepared for a very wide survey of things, all of which you might be out of your depth for.
100% yes. Scaz makes all of these topics super interesting, applicable, and fun even! It's also in Python, a language I've always wanted to learn.
Yes! Amazing course, great lectures, not too hard but still you learn a lot. Strongly recommend.
Yes, but be sure to go to office hours constantly.
Take it if you haven't taken Intelligent robotics or NLP. This was only good with scaz though
Yes! Good survey course, not super hard, but a bit disorganised. Take it just for the material and Scaz.

I would recommend the course because I think AI, in general, is very interesting and I think personally Professor Scaz is a great person; however, I do not think I gained a deep understanding of AI because this was mostly like a survey course.
